BPM214H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Socially Engaged Buddhism applies traditional Buddhist spiritual, ethical and social teachings to improve society. This course will focus on contemporary movements in Vietnam, Tibet, China & Taiwan, Sri Lanka, Thailand and India, as well as its ramifications in the West that have inspired movements such as Buddhist prison ministries and the Peacemaker Order.

BPM232H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Describes the psychology inherent within the original teachings of Buddhism. Primary focus is on the understanding of the causes of suffering and happiness, the nature of cognition and emotion, characteristics of the self/ego, personality transformation, the role of the unconscious, and mindfulness meditation. Includes an option for Community Engaged Learning experience.

BPM330H1-S-20219.courseDescription: An exploration of the current interest in incorporating mindfulness into western mental health interventions. Examines the concept of mindfulness closely to show how mindfulness is implicitly a component of western psychological theories and interventions. Also discussed is how mindfulness is used directly and indirectly as a psychological intervention.

BPM332H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Evaluates the relationship between Buddhist psychology and the practice of Western psychotherapy. Areas that will be studied include positive psychology, psychoanalysis, cognitive-behaviour therapy, mindfulness meditation and Jungian psychology. Comparisons with original Buddhist teachings and commentaries will be made.
BPM332H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions: Lectures are delivered online at the scheduled class time. Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and/or BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

BPM333H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Explores some important connections between Cognitive Science and Buddhism. In particular it will examine the insights of cognitive science into central Buddhist concepts such as wisdom, mindfulness, meditation, insight and self-control, as well as related concepts such as flow and mystical experience.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

BPM334H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Science of Wisdom: Buddhist and Western Traditions
BPM334H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Provides a conceptual and practical exploration of several ancient wisdom traditions. Buddhist approaches to self-actualization and wisdom will be compared to several other wisdom traditions (e.g. Mesopotamia, classical Greece, Christianity, Renaissance, etc.) Includes guided experiential exercises for each of the wisdom traditions.

BPM335H1-F-20219.courseDescription: In recent years, the effects of meditation on the body have been widely researched. There is an increasing body of evidence that mindfulness meditation can affect brain activity, brain structure, neurochemistry and other psychobiological processes (e.g. blood pressure, cardiac function). This course will examine the research in this emerging field.
BPM335H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be recorded and available asynchronously.  Discussions and tests will be administered during the scheduled class time.  Students must be available at the scheduled class time.  Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

BPM335H1-S-20219.courseDescription: In recent years, the effects of meditation on the body have been widely researched. There is an increasing body of evidence that mindfulness meditation can affect brain activity, brain structure, neurochemistry and other psychobiological processes (e.g. blood pressure, cardiac function). This course will examine the research in this emerging field.

BPM336H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
BPM336H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Topics vary from year to year depending on the instructor.

LEC-0101.subtitle: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues

BPM338H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Mindfulness meditation is a systematic investigation of subjective experience. Classic and modern descriptions of mindfulness and the recent scientific literature are surveyed. In addition to exploring a variety of meditative practices in the class, students are also required to maintain an ongoing meditation practice outside of class time over the duration of the course.
BPM338H1-F-20219.exclusion: NEW338H1, NEW432H1 (Advanced Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health: Cultivating Consciousness); offered in Fall 2012, Fall 2013, Fall 2014, Summer 2015, and Winter 2016

Classic and modern descriptions of mindfulness and the recent scientific literature are surveyed. BPM432H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Advanced Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
BPM432H1-S-20219.courseDescription: An upper-level seminar. Topics vary from year to year, depending on the instructor.

BPM433H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Advanced Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
BPM433H1-S-20219.courseDescription: An upper-level seminar. Topics vary from year to year, depending on the instructor.

LEC-0101.subtitle: Advanced Exploration of Buddhist Psychology & Dharma

BPM438H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Critically evaluates the empirical research literature relevant to the study of mindfulness meditation. Conceptual, methodological and interpretive limitations of the scientific literature are discussed. Comparisons between the scientific models of mindfulness meditation and Buddhist descriptions will be made.
BPM438H1-F-20219.prerequisite: A statistics course (e.g. PSY201H1, SOC202H1, STA220H1)
